data.title: Town Without Pity (1961)
data.meta_description: Four American soldiers stationed near a German village face death in the rape of a local girl and are defended by outside counsel Major Steve Grant.
data.text:
Cinematic Time Capsule

1961 Marathon - Film #9

”Personally, I hate your guts, but I have to defend you.”

Kirk Douglas is assigned to defend four American soldiers accused of raping a German girl in this really weird and dark courtroom drama.

The central moral quandary is interesting enough, but the film just feels off balance all the way through. There’s this odd voice-over, that pops up from time to time to translates the German rather than using subtitles. And the uptempo Oscar nominated theme song works great during the opening credits, but as it continues to play throughout the film it feels more and more out of place.

I also kept expecting the town to break out in a…

Not a film that is easy to reckon with, and I'll admit coming into it I was a bit concerned how a film from this period was going to be tackling the trial of a rape case from the perspective of the defense attorney. And in this instance, we know they're guilty. However, I'd argue it actually is pretty progressive in many respects as it is an examination of the complication of technically doing the duty, as everyone is supposed to get a fair trail even horrible criminal as is the case for our rapists, but in doing so committing a second crime against the victim. And it poses that question and unravels it with painful brutality. And one may…

This German/US co-production is a highly compelling drama about the riverside gang rape of a young German girl by four drunken American G.I.'s (including a young Robert Blake and Richard Jaeckel) stationed near a Bavarian village within occupied Germany. There is enough interesting location shooting, artful black and white compositions and economical courthouse debate and cross-examination that the film never feels bound to the courtroom or seems like a dry police procedural. The film treads dangerously close to the line between blaming the victim and indicting those that blame the victim, as represented by Kirk Douglas' morally conflicted defence attorney character who must save his clients from the electric chair by smearing a young girl's increasingly shaky reputation.
